title: Lac qui Parle County Airport
text:
Lac qui Parle County Airport is a public use <a href="airport">airport</a> in <a href="Lac%20qui%20Parle%20County%2C%20Minnesota">Lac qui Parle County, Minnesota</a>, United States. Also known as Bud Frye Field,<ref name="Mn/DOT">
</ref> it is located two <a href="nautical%20mile">nautical mile</a>s (4 <a href="kilometre">km</a>) southeast of the <a href="central%20business%20district">central business district</a> of <a href="Madison%2C%20Minnesota">Madison</a>. The airport opened in 2001 and it is owned by Lac qui Parle County and the cities of Madison and <a href="Dawson%2C%20Minnesota">Dawson</a>.
This airport is included in the <a href="National%20Plan%20of%20Integrated%20Airport%20Systems">National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems</a> for 2017–2021, which <a href="FAA%20airport%20categories">categorized</a> it as a "<a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a>" facility. Although many U.S. airports use the same three-letter <a href="location%20identifier">location identifier</a> for the <a href="Federal%20Aviation%20Administration">FAA</a> and <a href="International%20Air%20Transport%20Association">IATA</a>, this airport is assigned DXX by the FAA but has no designation from the IATA.
Facilities and aircraft.
Lac qui Parle County Airport covers an area of 257 <a href="acre">acre</a>s (104 <a href="hectare">ha</a>) at an <a href="elevation">elevation</a> of 1,083 feet (330 m) above <a href="mean%20sea%20level">mean sea level</a>. It has two <a href="runway">runway</a>s: 14/32 is 3,300 by 75 feet (1,006 x 23 m) with an <a href="asphalt">asphalt</a> surface and 9/27 is 3,003 by 135 feet (915 x 41 m) with a <a href="grass">turf</a> surface.
For the 12-month period ending October 31, 2014, the airport had 2,160 <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a> aircraft operations, an average of 180 per month. In January 2017, there were 10 aircraft based at this airport: 9 single-engine and 1 multi-engine.
